Embroiled in Oil

Embroiled in Oil
Pin It

from Hemmings Classic Car

November, 2010 - Jim Richardson

Let's talk about oil, that odiferous muck from the netherworld that makes our modern world possible. Without it, most of us would be walking to work, and our roads would be paved with an amalgam of dust and horse excreta.

Oil is a hot potato these days, with the recent Gulf spill, and I don't want to talk politics. But there are some things every classic car buff should know about the automotive products that we make from the stuff. Things like: Our old cars were designed to run on it and be lubricated by it. Sure, you can burn alcohol or propane or even wood, but those don't work as well as gasoline.

As an example of what I am talking about, propane produces less power and more heat in your engine, and you will have to carry a big pressurized tank of it to power your car. And alcohol provides only 70 percent of the energy of gasoline, so you will need to burn nearly twice as much of it to get from A to B.

Hot rodders have been running alcohol forever, as have the Indianapolis racers, but that is because you can increase the compression ratio of the engine for racing, and because alcohol is less likely to explode in a crash. It's not because it's a great alternative to gasoline. Indy cars have little engines, but only get about 1.5 miles per gallon.

There are myths surrounding gasoline that old car buffs should know about, too. To begin with, it doesn't matter which brand of gas you run in your car. That's right: It's all refined to SAE standards, and the cut-rate stations buy the excess from the few big refiners--so at the cut-rate station, you get the same fuel you would at the full retail station.

The second myth about gasoline is that high octane ratings help an engine that does not have high-compression cylinder heads. Not true. All octane boosters do is prevent detonation, and most old cars--other than the high-compression, high-performance muscle cars of the late Fifties, Sixties and early Seventies--don't have a problem running low-octane fuel.

As an example, my 1940 Packard runs just great on unleaded gas, as does my 1955 Chevy. In fact, the Packard would be fine with 76-octane fuel. I know this because Union 76 gasoline was named that in the 1930s, not out of patriotism, but to tout their 76-octane gas, which was hot stuff back then. Check with your mechanic, and then try regular gas in your classic. If it doesn't ping or knock, and you don't drive it hard, it'll be fine.

Engine oil is a different story. That's because since 1975, when modern catalytic converters debuted, refiners have eliminated the sulfur and zinc compounds in automotive oil because these ingredients clog converters. To make it work, the carmakers have gone to roller tappets in their valvetrains. You see, the zinc sulfur compound provided a sacrificial metal that kept flat-tappet cams from galling, and pistons from scuffing and wearing out. It also filled in pitted bearing surfaces and made engines last longer.

I found out about this the hard way when I put a mild cam in a 1957 Chevy straight-six a while back, in an effort to boost performance. The engine ran great until the lobes on the cam went flat. They couldn't survive without those zinc dithiophosphates that engine oil had in it back when our classics were built.

So how do you deal with this problem? There are three ways. You can add oil additives that include ZZDP. It's recommended for everything from Model T Fords to vintage muscle cars. Another alternative is to do what I do and use specially formulated oil that contains plenty of zinc-sulfur compound.

Finally, you can help your pre-catalytic converter engine survive by using oil intended for diesel trucks. The powers that be are busy taking the sulfur-zinc compound out of it, too, but there's still enough at this point to help your engine live a bit longer. You can get diesel engine oil at most auto supply stores or at the nearest truck stop.

I hope this advice helps keep your classic healthy. Contact me at jameshr106@aol.com if you have questions.

# **Classic Car Restoration Garage: A Multi-Agent Collaboration Hub**  

## **1. Overall Scene Theme and Core Concept**  
A bustling **classic car restoration garage**, where mechanics, engineers, and apprentices work together to revive vintage automobiles. The environment thrives on collaboration—heavy engine blocks require multiple hands, intricate diagnostics demand shared expertise, and scattered tools necessitate coordinated retrieval. The space is rich with **oil-stained floors**, **vintage posters**, and **half-dismantled vehicles**, creating an immersive, task-dense setting.  

### **Why Multi-Agent?**  
- **Heavy object handling** (engines, transmissions, car bodies).  
- **Tool coordination** (specialized wrenches, diagnostic tools).  
- **Chemical management** (fuel, solvents, lubricants).  
- **Documentation & communication** (repair manuals, schematics, part orders).  

---  

## **2. Spatial Layout and Area Descriptions**  
The garage is divided into **four key zones**, each with distinct functions:  

1. **Main Work Bay** – Central area with two car lifts, tool chests, and a hydraulic press.  
2. **Parts & Storage Room** – Shelves of labeled bins, crates of salvaged components, and a locked chemical cabinet.  
3. **Diagnostic & Office Corner** – Cluttered desk with manuals, a vintage computer, and a wall of blueprints.  
4. **Welding & Fabrication Zone** – Metal sheets, welding torches, and a partially assembled custom exhaust.  

---  

## **3. Detailed Area-by-Area Inventory**  

### **A. Main Work Bay**  
**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- Two **hydraulic car lifts** (one occupied by a disassembled 1957 Chevy, the other empty).  
- A **500kg engine hoist** on a rolling gantry (chain slightly rusted).  
- A **steel workbench** (scratched, grease-stained, bolted to the floor).  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **Flat-tappet camshaft (worn, lobes visibly flattened)** – Critical for diagnosing oil failure.  
- **Five oil bottles** (one with **"ZZDP additive" handwritten label**, others generic brands).  
- **A 150kg engine block** (suspended mid-transfer, requiring two agents to stabilize).  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **Pneumatic impact wrench** (hissing from a slow air leak).  
- **Oil drain pan** (half-full with black sludge).  
- **Digital calipers** (battery low, screen flickering).  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **Framed 1950s gas station ads** (sun-faded).  
- **Coffee mug labeled "World’s Okayest Mechanic"** (holding loose bolts).  
- **Stack of old Hemmings Classic Car magazines** (dog-eared, oil-smudged).  

---  

### **B. Parts & Storage Room**  
**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- **Heavy-duty shelving units** (overloaded, slightly bent under weight).  
- **Locked chemical cabinet** (requires keycard from office drawer).  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **Diesel engine oil jugs** (labeled **"15W-40 High Zinc"**).  
- **Sealed crate** ("**Fragile – 1965 Mustang Grille**", requires two people to lift).  
- **Mismatched spark plugs** (one has **unique copper tip** for high-compression engines).  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **Label maker** (out of tape).  
- **Parts washer tub** (dirty solvent needs replacing).  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **Dusty "Safety First" poster** (peeling at corners).  
- **Pile of discarded cardboard boxes** (some marked "Vintage GM Parts").  

---  

### **C. Diagnostic & Office Corner**  
**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- **Rolling office chair** (one wheel missing).  
- **Wall-mounted blueprint rack** (overflowing with schematics).  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **Vintage repair manual** (open to "Flat-Tappet Cam Failures").  
- **Keycard** (hidden under coffee-stained invoice, unlocks chemical cabinet).  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **Landline phone** (off-hook, faint dial tone).  
- **Printer** (out of paper, error light blinking).  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **Calendar from 1987** (never flipped past June).  
- **Ashtray full of pencil shavings** (no actual ash).  

---  

### **D. Welding & Fabrication Zone**  
**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- **Welding table** (burnt marks, clamp still attached).  
- **Oxy-acetylene torch setup** (hoses tangled).  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **Half-welded exhaust pipe** (needs precise alignment before finishing).  
- **Leather welding apron** (hung up, one strap torn).  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **Angle grinder** (cord frayed near plug).  
- **Metal scraps bin** (overflowing).  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **"Employee of the Month" plaque** (blank nameplate).  
- **Charred Hot Wheels car** (melted into table).  

---  

## **4. Scene Affordances and Embedded Potential**  

### **Collaborative Transportation Affordances:**  
- **The 150kg engine block** (requires two agents to maneuver safely).  
- **The "Fragile" Mustang grille crate** (bulky, awkward for solo lifting).  

### **Reasoning & Tool-Use Affordances:**  
- **Attribute-Based:** Among five oil bottles, only the **"ZZDP additive"** has a **handwritten label, blue cap, and half-full level**. Nearby **decorative blue solvent bottles** act as distractors.  
- **Compound Problem-Solving:**  
  - **Problem:** Locked chemical cabinet.  
  - **Solution:** Keycard hidden under an invoice in the office.  
  - **Challenge:** Requires navigating multiple zones and identifying the correct document.  

---  

### **Final Notes**  
This garage is a **dense, purposeful environment** where every object tells a story. Agents must:  
- **Collaborate on heavy lifts.**  
- **Differentiate nearly identical items.**  
- **Solve multi-step tool-use problems.**  
- **Navigate realistic workplace clutter.**  

The scene is **alive with potential tasks**, from diagnosing cam failure to welding a custom exhaust—all while maneuvering through a space where **every detail matters**.
